 Add-ons and integrations 
You can extend the functionality of IBM® Cloud Pak for Data through add-ons and
by integrating Cloud Pak for Data with other applications.  
 Add-ons 
Add-ons are services that are deployed in your Cloud Pak for Data cluster. For more
information about the add-ons that are available for Cloud Pak for Data, see Add-
ons 
 Integrations 
Integrations are connections to applications that run outside of your Cloud Pak for
Data cluster. For more information about the applications that you can integrate
with, see Integrations. 
 
Add-ons 
 The IBM Cloud Pak for Data web client includes a catalog of add-ons that you can
use to extend the functionality of Cloud Pak for Data.
Integrations 
 Integrations are connections to applications that run outside of your IBM Cloud
Pak for Data cluster.

 Add-ons 
The IBM® Cloud Pak for Data web client includes a catalog of add-ons that you can
use to extend the functionality of Cloud Pak for Data. 
 Accessing the list of add-ons 
To access the list of add-ons that you can install on top of Cloud Pak for Data: 
From the toolbar, click the Add-ons icon ( ).
Click the add-on you want to learn more about.
If you're ready to use the add-on to extend your Cloud Pak for Data environment,
click Get started.
Some add-ons are provided free of charge, while other add-ons are priced. 
Currently, the catalog includes the following types of add-ons:
AI
Analytics
Dashboards
Data governance
Data sources
Developer tools
Industry accelerators
Storage

 Installing the Watson  Assistant for Voice
Interaction add-on 
You can install the add-ons that comprise Watson™  Assistant for Voice Interaction
on top of IBM® Cloud Pak for Data 
 Introduction 
Watson  Assistant for Voice Interaction is a set of add-ons for IBM Cloud Pak for
Data that deliver a Watson based voice automation system. This system can be
integrated with SIP based telephone systems to deliver a cognitive assistant as an
interactive voice response (IVR) system that understands what an end user is
saying through the use of natural language understanding, and responds in real-
time using voices built on neural technologies. 
The add-ons and products included with Watson  Assistant for Voice Interaction are: 
Watson  Assistant 
Watson Speech to Text 
Watson Text to Speech 
IBM Voice Gateway 
 Prerequisites 
Watson  Assistant for Voice Interaction requires version 2.1.0.2 of IBM Cloud Pak
for Data. For more information, see the IBM Cloud Pak for Data system
requirements. 
The following number of VPCs are required to setup a minimum install of Watson
Assistant for Voice Interaction: Table 1. Number of VPCs required
 
 Assuming voice only, you will need a minimum of 27 VPCs for Watson  Assistant
for Voice Interaction plus the number of VPCs required by IBM Cloud Pak for Data.
This will provide capacity for 11 concurrent calls. To calculate VPC requirements
beyond the minimum, you can use this calculator. 
 Install Watson add-ons 
Instructions for installing each of these individual add-ons can be found at the
following links: 
Installing the Watson Assistant add-on 
Installing the Watson Speech-to-Text add-on

 Configure and install IBM Voice Gateway 
After the above add-ons and IBM Voice Gateway have been installed, you will need
to follow the steps below to configure the installed components, along with
configuring and installing Voice Gateway to work together. These steps will assume
that the above services have been installed on the same IBM Cloud Pak for Data
cluster, however, you should be able to use them as a guide if your services are
deployed across separate clusters. 
Before you begin, it's best to use a system where the following are available: 
kubectl cli - Kubernetes command line interface 
oc cli - Red Hat OpenShift command line interface 
openssl 
keytool - available with Java SDKs 
 Installing Voice Gateway on IBM Cloud Pak for Data with
OpenShift 
Before you install IBM Voice Gateway, you must install and configure the Helm
client and the Kubernetes command-line tool. 
Downloading installation artifacts
Use the Secure Shell protocol to log in as the root user to the system that you use
as the master node of your cluster.
Change to the directory where you want the installation files to be stored.
Download the archive files.
 
Logging onto OpenShift and the Docker registryUse the following commands to
log in.docker login -u $(oc whoami) -p $(oc whoami -t) {docker-registry}
 
 
The {docker-registry} option is the address of the internal OpenShiftDocker
registry. An example of the registry is docker-registry.default.svc:5000. 
 
Creating a namespaceFrom the OpenShift command-line tool, create the
namespace in which to deploy the service. Run the following command to create the
namespace:oc new-project {namespace-name} 
 
 
Pointing to the correct OpenShift projectRun the following command:oc project
{namespace-name} 
 
The {namespace-name} option is the Docker namespace that hosts the Docker
image. You created this namespace in a previous step. 
 
Red Hat OpenShiftSecurityContextConstraints requirementsThis chart
requires a SecurityContextConstraints object to be bound to the target
namespace before installation. To meet this requirement, actions that are scoped for
clusters and namespaces might need to occur before and after the binding. 
The hostaccess name, which is a predefined SecurityContextConstraints
name, was verified for this chart. If your target namespace is bound to this
SecurityContextConstraints resource, you can install the chart. 
49
Run the following command to bind the SecurityContextConstraints resource
to your namespace:oc adm policy add-scc-to-group hostaccess
       system:serviceaccounts:{namespace-name} 
 
 Alternatively, you can also use a custom SecurityContextConstraints resource like
the following one:apiVersion: security.openshift.io/v1
kind: SecurityContextConstraints
metadata:

allowHostDirVolumePlugin: true
allowHostIPC: false
allowHostNetwork: true
allowHostPID: false
allowHostPorts: true
allowPrivilegedContainer: false
allowPrivilegeEscalation: false
defaultAllowPrivilegeEscalation: false
forbiddenSysctls:
 - "*"
fsGroup:
 type: MustRunAs

 - max: 65535
   min: 1
readOnlyRootFilesystem: false
requiredDropCapabilities:
- ALL
runAsUser:
 type: MustRunAsNonRoot
seccompProfiles:
- docker/default
seLinuxContext:
 type: RunAsAny
supplementalGroups:
 type: MustRunAs
 ranges:
 - max: 65535
   min: 1
volumes:
- configMap
- downwardAPI
- emptyDir
- persistentVolumeClaim
- projected
- secret 
 
Extracting the PPA archive contentsRun the following command:cd {compressed-file-
dir}

The {compressed-file-dir} option is the name of the directory that you
downloaded {compressed_file-name} to. The {compressed-file-name}
option is the name of the file that you downloaded from Passport Advantage. 
 
Loading the Docker images into the OpenShiftDocker registryRun the following
command:cd {compressed-file-dir}/pak_extensions/cp4d
./loadImagesOpenShift.sh --path {compressed_file_dir} --namespace {namespace-name} --registry {docker-
registry}
 
 
The {docker-registry} option is the address of the internal OpenShiftDocker
registry, as shown in the following example:docker-registry.default.svc:5000 
 
If the command is successful, the Docker images exist in the OpenShiftDocker
registry. You can check the loaded images by using command: kubectl get images | grep
{namespace-name} 
 
If you cannot access the Kubernetes command-line tool, see Enabling access to
kubectl CLI for instructions. 
 
 Configuration 
Configuring the tenant configurationIf you haven't already do so, you will need to
create a multi-tenant configuration file and a Watson  Assistant skill for both the
Voice Gateway and the SMS Gateway.
Voice Gateway
You should start with a Voice Gateway multi-tenant JSON config file to allow you
to configure a tenant as you follow these steps. You can find a template for a
Voice Gateway multi-tenant configuration file here.
This file is referred to as the tenantConfig.json file below.
For Watson  Assistant, you'll need to add a workspace with a dialog. You can
quickly get started by importing the conversation/sample-conversation-en.json
file.
SMS Gateway (optional)
You should start with a Voice Gateway multi-tenant JSON configuration file, to
allow you to configure a tenant as you follow these steps. Sample multi-tenant
config file.
This file is referred to as the sms-tenantConfig.json file below.
See Create a Watson Assistant workspace in the Configure a Watson Assistant
workspace topic.Note: This workspace may be in the same or different Watson
Assistant instance as that of the Voice Gateway. 
 
 
Obtaining bearer tokens for the Watson Speech and Watson  Assistant

servicesBearer tokens are used by Voice Gateway to authenticate with each of the
Watson services when connections are established. This section explains how to
acquire the bearer tokens for each service instance. 
Access the bearer tokens and service URLs from Watson Speech to Text,
Watson Text to Speech and Watson  Assistant.
Logon to the IBM Cloud Pak for Data administration console where instances
for each of the Watson Services has been created.
Click on the Add-ons icon on the upper right hand corner to display the Add-on
tiles.
For each service, click on the three vertical dots in the upper right hand corner
of the tile.
Select Manage Instances. From the new page that displays, hover over the
instance that you want, click on the three horizontal dots to the right of that
instance, and select View Details.
In the upper right select Show, which will display the Access Token, a.k.a the
bearerToken. You'll need both the:
Access Token and
URL
For the Watson  Assistant, you will also need the skill's workspace ID. If you have
not yet created a Watson  Assistant skill, you can start by importing a sample skill
you can download from here:
https://github.com/WASdev/sample.voice.gateway/blob/master/conversation/sam
ple-conversation-en.json. If you already have a skill, skip to 2e below to obtain its
workspace ID
On the View Details page of your Watson Assistant instance, click the Launch
Tool button.
Select the Skills tab and click the Create Skill button.
With Dialog Skill checked, click Next.
Choose the Import Skill tab and select the downloaded JSON file.
Return to the Skills tab to see the tile representing your imported skill.
Click on the 3 vertical dots of the tile and choose View API Details.

 SSL configuration between the IBM Voice Gateway and the
Watson Services on IBM Cloud Pak for Data 
The default self-signed certificate generated by CP4D will not work for the WAVI
integration. Instead, you have two choices for enabling SSL between Voice Gateway
and the Watson Services. These include:
Generate public and private keys and configure them at each of the services or
Disable SSL certificate validation in the IBM Voice Gateway
 
Note:Permanently disabling certificate validation is not recommended, but this can
be done to verify that the initial configuration is correct before adding SSL certificate
validation. 
 
Setting up your own certificate authorityWhile you can use certificates from a
trusted Certificate Authority, another option is to setup your own for generating
public and private keys. This section explains how to do that: 
53
1.
2.
3.
Issue the following two commands to create your own CA root certificate:openssl
genrsa -out rootCA.key 4096 
openssl req -x509 -new -nodes -key rootCA.key -sha256 -days 1024 -out rootCA.pem 
Note: The second command will prompt for responses. For the Common name
you can enter in anything, such as your name. 
Generate private key and certificate signing request for the IBM Cloud Pak for
Data NGINX pods. If you're using separate IBM Cloud Pak for Data clusters to
host each of the Watson Services you can use an openssl.cnf file to specify
more than one host,. An example is provided below.You'll want to add hostnames
and IP addresses for any system that you might want to access the NGINX pods
on. 
openssl.cnf file example: 
[req]
distinguished_name = req_distinguished_name
req_extensions = v3_req
 
[req_distinguished_name]
countryName = Country Name (2 letter code)
countryName_default = US
stateOrProvinceName = State or Province Name
stateOrProvinceName_default = NC
localityName = Locality Name (e.g. city)
localityName_default = RTP
OrganizationalUnitName = Organizational Unit Name (eg, section)
OrganizationalUnitName_default = Your company
commonName = NGINC CP4D pods
commonName_MAX = 64
 
[v3_req]
# Extensions to add to certificate request
basicConstraints = CA:FALSE
keyUsage = nonRepudiation, digitalSignature, keyEncipherment
subjectAltName = @alt_names
 
[alt_names]
DNS.1 = cp4d-1.your-company.com
DNS.2 = cp4d-2.your-company.com
IP.1 = 10.190.155.241
IP.2 = 10.190.253.117 
Once you create the openssl.cnf file, you need to create a key and a
certificate signing request (CSR) referencing the file (if using a true CA, the CSR
would be sent to the CA for signing): 
openssl genrsa -out cert.key 4096
openssl req -new -key cert.key -out cert.csr -config openssl.cnf 
Note: The second command will prompt for information. It's okay to just hit Enter
to accept the defaults. 
Sign the CSR with the rootCA key (not needed if using a true certificate authority)
openssl x509 -req -in cert.csr -CA rootCA.pem -CAkey rootCA.key -CAcreateserial -out cert.crt -days 1000

The above instructions generate three files that you will need for the rest of the
configuration:
rootCA.pem
cert.key
cert.crt
Note: The first file will be placed in a truststore for the IBM Voice Gateway; the
last two files will be copied to the NGINX servers that sit in front of the Watson
Services. 
 
Making the new certificates available to the IBM Cloud Pak for Data NGINX
pods
From the system where you have the cert.key and cert.crt files, connect to
the Red Hat OpenShift cluster that hosts the Watson Services that you wish to
use with the oc cli utility. For example:oc login localhost:8443 --username=myuser --
password=mypass 
Set context to the Project where IBM Cloud Pak for Data has been deployed. For
example:oc project zen 
Locate one of the ibm-nginx pods using commands:ibm_nginx_pod=$(oc get pods -n zen
| grep ibm-nginx | head -1 | cut -f1 -d\ )
echo $ibm_nginx_pod 
Create the customer-certs directory at a well-known location inside the podoc exec
${ibm_nginx_pod} -n zen -- mkdir -p "/user-home/_global_/customer-certs" 
Copy the files to the customer-certs locationoc cp cert.crt ${ibm_nginx_pod}:/user-
home/_global_/customer-certs/
oc cp cert.key ${ibm_nginx_pod}:/user-home/_global_/customer-certs/ 
Reload the new certificate in all the HTTPS NGINX pod replicas by running a
reload script for each pod:for i in `oc get pods -n zen | grep ibm-nginx |  cut -f1 -d\ `; do oc
exec ${I} -n zen -- /scripts/reload.sh; done 
You can verify that the new certificate is being delivered by accessing the IBM
Cloud Pak for Data console from a web browser; you should get a warning about
the certificate.
 
Making root cert available to the IBM Voice Gateway pods
If you've had to log into a different cluster to make the certificates available to the
NGINX servers, then you'll need to log back into the cluster where VGW is
installed.
To make the root CA available to the Media Relay, create a secret
clientCaCertFile using the rootCa.pem file created above.kubectl create secret
generic client-ca-cert-secret --from-file=clientCaCerFile=rootCA.pem 
Make the root CA available to the SIP Orchestrator:
Use the keytool command to create a JKS trust store filekeytool import --
trustcacerts -alias root -file rootCA.pem -keystore trust.jks 
Note: You'll be prompted to set a password for the new trust.jks file that
you are creating. 
If working with certificates from a trusted CA, you can add well-known signer
certificates to the trust store.keytool -importkeystore -srckeystore
$JAVA_HOME/jre/lib/security/cacert -destkeystore trust.jks

Create the secret for the SIP Orchestrator's trust storekubectl create secret generic
trust-store-file-secret --from-file=trustStoreFile=./trust.jks --namespace {namespace-name} 
Place the password that you assigned to trust.jks into a text fileecho -n "trust-
store-pw" > trust_pass.txt 
Create a secret sslPassphrase with the trust store passwordkubectl create
secret generic ssl-passphrase-secret --from-file=sslPassphrase=./trust_pass.txt 
The Voice Gateway and the SMS Gateway both use the same secret, but
different keys within that secret. So if you're also planning to configure the
SMS Gateway to use a Watson  Assistant instance on IBM Cloud Pak for Data
then you would want to issue this command to create the two keys:kubectl create
secret generic ssl-passphrase-secret --from-file=sslPassphrase=./trust_pass.txt --from-
file=sslTrustPassphrase=./trust_pass.txt --namespace {namespace-name} 
Make the root CA available to the SMS Gateway 
The SMS Gateway uses the same secret as the SIP Orchestrator for the trust
store, however it uses a different secret for the passphrase.kubectl create secret
generic ssl-trust-passphrase-secret --from-file=sslTrustPassphrase=./trust-pass.txt --namespace
{namespace-name} 
The SMS Gateway will also require secrets for the key store when SSL is
enabled. This example will use the trust store file to configure the required key
store secrets.kubectl create secret generic key-store-file-secret --from-
file=keyStoreFile=./trust.jks --namespace {namespace-name} 
Assuming that you're also deploying the IBM Voice Gateway into the same
cluster you'll need to create a secret that contains two keys for referencing the
password for the trust store. kubectl create secret generic ssl-passphrase-secret --from-
file=sslPassphrase=./trust_pass.txt --from-file=sslTrustPassphrase=./trust_pass.txt --namespace
{namespace-name} 
 
Customizing the configurationEdit values in the values.yaml file, which is
stored in the {compressed-file-dir}/charts/ibm-voice-gateway-prod
directory. 
At a minimum, you must provide your own values for the following configurable
setting:global.image.repository: Specify your docker registry URL, including your {namespace-name}, similar
to the following example: docker-registry.default.svc:5000/{namespace-name} 
 
 
Enabling SSL certificate validationOnce you have all of the secrets created, you'll
want to enable SSL validation:
Edit values in the values.yaml file, which is stored in the {compressed-
file-dir}/charts/ibm-voice-gateway-prod directory for your Helm
deployment:
Set enableSsl: true for the Media RelayenableSsl: true
 
Set enableSslorMutualAuth: true for the SIP Orchestrator
enableSslorMutualAuth: true
 
Enable SSL in the section for the SMS gateway: ssl:
 enable: true

Disabling SSL certificate validationIf you wish to bypass the above steps for
creating and deploying custom public and private keys you can simply disable SSL

Edit values in the values.yaml file, which is stored in the {compressed-

Creating the secret for the tenant configuration file
To make the IBM voice Gateway tenant configuration file available to the IBM
Voice Gateway service, you'll need to place it into a secret. For IBM Voice
Gateway:kubectl create secret generic vgw-tenantconfig-secret --from-
file=tenantConfig=tenantConfig.json --namespace {namespace-name}

session.

 Installing the Watson Knowledge Studio add-on 
You can install the Watson™ Knowledge Studio add-on on top of IBM® Cloud Pak
for Data. 
 Introduction 
Use Watson Knowledge Studio to create a machine learning model that
understands the linguistic nuances, meaning, and relationships specific to your
industry or to create a rule-based model that finds entities in documents based on
rules that you define. 
To become a subject matter expert in a given industry or domain, Watson must be
trained. You can facilitate the task of training Watson with Watson Knowledge
Studio. 
 Chart details 
This Helm chart installs a Cloud Pak for Data add-on of Watson Knowledge Studio.
Once the installation is completed, the Watson Knowledge Studio add-on becomes
available in the Cloud Pak for Data console. 
This chart deploys the following microservices per install:
Watson Knowledge Studio Front-end: Provides the Watson Knowledge Studio
tooling user interface.
Service Broker: Manages provisioning and de-provisioning of instances.
Dispatcher: Dispatches requests from gateway to Watson Knowledge Studio front
end.
SIREG: Tokenizers/parsers.
SIRE Job queue: Machine learning training framework that allows to queue and
schedule jobs on Kubernetes.
SIRE Train Facade: Manages interaction with the training framework and MinIO
storage.
Model Management API: Manages interaction with Watson Knowledge Studio
Front-end and Train Facade.
Watson Add-on: Publishes Watson Knowledge Studio service as a Cloud Pak for
Data add-on.
 
This chart installs the following stores:
PostgreSQL: Stores training metadata.
MongoDB: Stores WKS project data.
MinIO: Stores ML models and training data. 
 
 Prerequisites 
IBM Cloud Private 2.1.0.1
Kubernetes 1.12.4 or later
Helm 2.9.1 or later 
 
 PodSecurityPolicy requirements 
This chart requires a PodSecurityPolicy to be bound to the target namespace
prior to installation. The predefined PodSecurityPolicy name, ibm-
restricted-psp has been verified for this chart. If your target namespace is
bound to this PodSecurityPolicy resource, you can proceed to install the chart.
IBM Cloud Private v3.1 - Predefined PodSecurityPolicy name: ibm-restricted-
psp
94
- Custom PodSecurityPolicy definition:apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
kind: PodSecurityPolicy
metadata:
 annotations:
   kubernetes.io/description: "This policy is the most restrictive,
     requiring pods to run with a non-root UID, and preventing pods from accessing the host."
   #apparmor.security.beta.kubernetes.io/allowedProfileNames: runtime/default
   #apparmor.security.beta.kubernetes.io/defaultProfileName: runtime/default
   seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/allowedProfileNames: docker/default
   seccomp.security.alpha.kubernetes.io/defaultProfileName: docker/default
 name: ibm-watson-ks-psp
spec:
 allowPrivilegeEscalation: false
 forbiddenSysctls:
 - '*'
 fsGroup:
   ranges:
   - max: 65535
     min: 1
   rule: MustRunAs
 requiredDropCapabilities:
 - ALL
 runAsUser:
   rule: MustRunAsNonRoot
 seLinux:
   rule: RunAsAny
 supplementalGroups:
   ranges:
   - max: 65535
     min: 1
   rule: MustRunAs
 volumes:
 - configMap
 - emptyDir
 - projected
 - secret
 - downwardAPI
 - persistentVolumeClaim 
 
OpenShift SecurityContextConstraints Requirements This chart requires a
SecurityContextContraints to be bound to the target namespace prior to the
installation. To meet this requirement, there may be cluster scoped as well as
namespace scoped pre and post actions that need to occur.  
 The default SecurityContextConstraints name: restricted has been verified for
this chart. If your target namespace is bound to this
SecurityContextConstraints resource, you can proceed to install the chart.

Preparing persistent volumes for local-storageYou need this step only when you
use local-storage as a persistent volume. 
This chart uses persistent volumes for data stores. Local storage can be used for
this chart. To create a persistent volume with local-storage storage class, you
can define each volume configuration in a YAML file, and then use the kubectl
command line to push the configuration changes to the cluster. See Kubernetes
documentation for more details about local storage.
Create a local-storage storage class on your cluster. See Kubernetes
documentation for more detail.apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
kind: StorageClass
metadata:
 name: local-storage
provisioner: kubernetes.io/no-provisioner
volumeBindingMode: WaitForFirstConsumer 
Prepare directories to be used by PVs on worker nodes.
Create 8 YAML files, one for each volume. The number of required volumes can
be different if you change the number of replicas of data stores. Default is 8.

 Verifying the deployment 
After installing, you can verify the deployment with the following command. helm test
{release_name} --cleanup --timeout 600 --tls 
 
Accessing Watson Knowledge Studio tooling UIAfter the successful installation,
a Watson Knowledge Studio add-on tile with the release name appears in your
Cloud Pak for Data console. You can provision a Watson Knowledge Studio
instance and launch your Watson Knowledge Studio tooling application there.
 Open https://{cluster_CA_domain}:31843 with your web browser and
login to Cloud Pak for Data console.
Go to the add-on catalog. You can find the Watson Knowledge Studio add-on and
the release name.
Click the Watson Knowledge Studio add-on tile and provision an instance.
Open the created instance and click Launch Tool.
You can start using Watson Knowledge Studio.
 
 
 Uninstalling the chart 
Delete the existing WKS instances of the release on Cloud Pak for Data console.
Run the following command to uninstall and delete the existing release.helm delete -
-tls {release_name} 
{release_name}
is the Helm release name of this installation.
To irrevocably uninstall and delete the release, run the following command:helm
delete --tls --no-hooks --purge {release_name} 
 
 
If you omit the --purge option, Helm deletes all resources for the deployment but
retains the record with the release name. This approach allows you to roll back the
deletion. If you include the --purge option, Helm removes all records for the
deployment so that the name can be used for another installation. 
Before you can install a new version of the service on the same cluster, you must
remove all content from any persistent volumes and persistent volume claims that
were used for the previous deployment.

 Installing the Watson Natural Language
Understanding add-on 
You can install the Watson™ Natural Language Understanding add-on on top of
IBM® Cloud Pak for Data. 
Parent topic:Installing AI add-ons 
 
 Installation prerequisites 
 Procedure 
 
The cluster is running with the AVX2 CPU extension. To verify that it is: cat
/proc/cpuinfo 
 
Cloud Pak for Data has been installed
The user installing this add-on has full administrative privileges
Persistent volumes have been configured (without persistent volumes, custom
models will be lost if pods roll over.) See Storage Class and Persistent Volume Set
Up section.
 
 Storage Class and Persistent Volume Set Up 
 About this task 
 
A Persistent Volume (PV) is a unit of storage in the cluster. In the same way that a
node is a cluster resource, a persistent volume is also a resource in the cluster. For
an overview, see Persistent Volumes in the Kubernetes documentation at
https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSQNUZ_2.1.0/com.ibm.icpdata.doc
/zen/admin/install-storage-add-ons.html. 
You can use a Cloud Pak for Data storage add-on, or a storage option that is hosted
outside the cluster, such as vSphere Cloud Provider (
https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSBS6K_3.1.2/manage_cluster/vsp
here_land.html). Note the storage class volume type requirements below when
selecting your storage options. 
Supported Storage Class Volume Types for Watson Natural Language
Understanding Datastores:
MinIO
portworx-volume
glusterfs
vsphere-volume

portworx-volume
vsphere-volume

vsphere-volume

kubectl get storageclass

 Installing on Cloud Pak for Data with OpenShift 
 Procedure 
 
Purchase and download the Watson Natural Language Understanding archive
(.tgz file)
Use secure copy (scp) to copy the Watson Natural Language Understanding
archive to your Cloud Pak for Data master node.scp {local_file_location}
root@{master_node}:/ibm/InstallPackage/modules/ 
 
Log in as root to the master node of your Cloud Pak for Data.ssh root@{master_node} 
 
Log in to the OpenShift cluster.oc login 
 
Untar the Watson Natural Language Understanding archive (.tgz file) file you
downloaded. For example, to the following location: /ibm/InstallPackage/modules/
.cd /ibm/InstallPackage/modules/
tar -xvf {filename} 
 
Install Watson Natural Language Understanding:There are two pre-defined files
that contain the minimum development and production settings:
/ibm/InstallPackage/modules/nlu/dev-value-overrides.yaml

 Installing the  Watson API Kit add-ons 
You can install the add-ons that comprise the Watson™ API Kit on top of IBM®
Cloud Pak for Data. 
 About this task 
 
Watson API Kit includes the following add-ons:
Watson Knowledge Studio

Watson Speech to Text
Watson Text to Speech
 
For an overview of Watson API Kit, see Watson API Kit add-on. 
To install the add-ons, see the steps for each service that you want to install:
Installing the Watson Knowledge Studio add-on
Installing the Watson Natural Language Understanding add-on
Installing the Watson Speech to Text add-on

 Installing the Watson  Assistant add-on 
You can install the Watson™  Assistant add-on on top of IBM® Cloud Pak for Data. 
 About this task 
Use the Watson  Assistant add-on for Cloud Pak for Data to build conversational
interfaces into any app, device, or channel. 
 System requirements 
For details of the minimum requirements that must be met to support Cloud Pak for
Data itself, see System requirements. 
Add-on requirementsBefore you install the add-on, ensure that you have sufficient
resources to run the add-on. The following resources are required in addition to the
minimum platform requirements.
In development
Minimum worker nodes: 3
Minimum CPU available: 7
Minimum memory available: 75Gi
Minimum disk per node available: 500 GB
In production
 Minimum worker nodes: 4
Minimum CPU available: 10
Minimum memory available: 120Gi
Minimum disk per node available: 500 GB 
 
 
Optimal deployment configuration for developmentTable 1. Hardware verified to
support a development deployment of the add-on with Cloud Pak for Data
 
 
Important: Keep in mind that in a cluster environment, where CPU and memory are
assigned to containers dynamically, CPU and memory resources can become
stranded on nodes, leaving insufficient resources to schedule subsequent
workloads. In particular, the process of training a machine learning model requires
at least one node to have 4 CPUs that can be dedicated to training. This capacity is
only needed when training occurs, which happens after changes are made to the
training data for an assistant. 
The systems that host Watson  Assistant must meet these requirements:
Watson  Assistant for Cloud Pak for Data can run on Intel architecture nodes only.
CPUs must have 2.4 GHz or higher clock speed
CPUs must support Linux SSE 4.2
CPUs must support the AVX2 instruction set extension. See the Advanced Vector
Extensions Wikipedia page for a list of CPUs that include this support (most CPUs
since 2012). The service cannot function properly without AVX2 support.

Language considerationsThe components that are necessary to process natural
languages require significant amounts of data. The base set of supported languages
require 40 GB of memory per node. The following languages require that you add
additional resources to support them: Table 2. Language resource requirements
 
 
Each of these languages requires an additional VPC for a production deployment
and an additional 1/2 VPC for a development deployment. 
For the full list of supported languages, see Supported languages. 
 
MicroservicesMicroservices are individual components that together comprise a
service. Watson  Assistant consists of the following microservices:
NLU (Natural Language Understanding)
Interface for store to communicate with the back-end to initiate ML training.
Dialog
Dialog runtime, or user-chat capability
ed-mm
Manages contextual entity capabilities.
Master
Controls the lifecycle of underlying intent and entity models.
Recommends
Supports recommendations from Watson, such as dictionary-based entity
synonyms and intent conflicts.
SIREG
Manages tokenization and system entity capabilities.
skill-conversation
Manages dialog skills.
skill-search
Manages search skills.
SLAD
Manages service training capabilities.
Store
API endpoints.
TAS
Manages services model inferencing.

Provides the developer user interface.
 
In addition to these microservices, the Helm chart installs the following resources:
PostgreSQL
Stores training data. Includes the components keeper, sentinel, and proxy.
MongoDB
Stores word vectors.
Redis
Used by the Watson  Assistant tool to store web session-related data.
etcd
Manages service registration and discovery.
MinIO
Stores CLU models.
 
 
 Storage requirements 
The following table lists the storage resources that are required to support a
deployment that uses local storage:  Table 3. Storage requirements
 
 
 Creating persistent volumes 
A PersistentVolume (PV) is a unit of storage in the cluster. In the same way that
a node is a cluster resource, a persistent volume is also a resource in the cluster. 
For an overview, see Persistent Volumes in the Kubernetes documentation. 
Follow the correct procedure for your deployment.
Creating persistent volumes for a production environment
Creating persistent volumes for a development environment
 
 Creating persistent volumes for a production environment 
To deploy resilient storage in a production environment, do not use the script that is
provided in the archive file. The script creates local storage volumes that are meant
for deployments into a development or test environment. 
Instead, consider using an IBM Cloud Pak for Data storage add-on or a storage
option that is hosted outside the cluster, such as vSphere Cloud Provider.
Portworx: If you choose to use Portworx, you do not need to create persistent
volumes before you install the product. Portworx dynamically creates persistent
volumes.When enabled, Portworx grabs unmounted disks to use. For example, if
you have 7 worker nodes in your cluster, 4 of which have umounted disks of 400G
each, Portworx might provision each worker node with 3 to 4 pods-worth of

MongoDB 3 80 GB local-storage

To use Portworx storage with a stand-alone deployment of IBM Cloud Pak for Data
:
Follow the instructions for installing Portworx on Kubernetes helm. See
Installing storage add-ons.
After installing the storage, edit the spec.yaml file that is generated by the
Portworx spec generator.
Change the node-get-put-list-role ClusterRole podsecuritypolicies to
the following value:- apiGroups: ['policy']
resources: ['podsecuritypolicies']
verbs:     ['use']
resourceNames:
- 'ibm-privileged-psp'
 
To prevent ImagePullBackOff errors from occuring, add the following
information to the file, where sa-kube-system is the secret name for the
kube-system namespace where Portworx is installed. Specify whatever
secret name you used.imagePullSecrets:
- name: "sa-kube-system"
 
Run the following command to apply the changes you made:kubectl apply -f
spec.yaml 
Define the storage class.Create a YAML file in which you define the storage
class for the persistent volume. kind: StorageClass
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: portworx-shared-sc
provisioner: kubernetes.io/portworx-volume
parameters:
   repl: "3"
   shared: "true"
   priority_io: "high"
   snap_interval: "0"
   io_profile: "db"
   block_size: "64k"
 
 
Push the configuration change to the cluster. Use the apply command in a
command with the following syntax: kubectl apply -f {storage-class-yaml-file-name} 
Configure Watson  Assistant for Cloud Pak for Data to use the storage. Override
the persistent volume storage class setting in the values.yaml file. By default, it
is set to use local-storage. You can specify portworx-shared-sc
instead. This class sets the provisioner to kubernetes.io/portworx-volume.
Specifically, you must override the following values:
minio.persistence.storageClass: portworx-shared-sc
etcd.config.dataPVC.storageClassName: portworx-shared-sc
postgres.config.persistence.storageClassName: portworx-shared-sc

For information about how to override values in the values.yaml file, see one of the
following sections:
OpenShift: Customize the configuration
Stand-alone: Customize the configuration
 
 
 Creating persistent volumes for a development environment 
A script named createLocalVolumePV.sh is included in the archive file that you
can use to create persistent volumes for a development deployment only.Important:
Do not use the script to create persistent volumes for a production deployment. 
 
When you install the service, persistent volume claims are created for the
components automatically. However, when the preferred storage class for the
service is local-storage, which is the default setting, you must explicitly create the
persistent volumes in the cluster before you install the service. 
Because the script that you need to run is included in the archive package, you
cannot create the volumes until after you download and unpack the PPA archive file
for the Helm chart. Start the installation process and return to this section when you
get to the point in the procedure where the persistent volumes must be created. Skip
to Before you begin. 
Use the createLocalVolumePV.sh script to create persistent volumes that are
bounded to cluster nodes where data stores such as MongoDB and Postgres will
run. Volumes that you create with the script are assigned a label that is used later to
bound each volume to the correct datastore pods. You provide the label and its
value to helm by specifying them in the wa-persistence.yaml file. 
Be careful if you need to update or stop a node with bounded local-storage
persistent volumes to perform maintenance tasks. 
To enable node affinity:
Create a file named wa-persistence.yaml that adds configuration values that
prevent dynamic provisioning from being applied to the volumes. You will
reference this YAML file from the --values parameter when you install the
product.cos: 
minio:   
 persistence:     
  useDynamicProvisioning: false     
  selector:       
   label: "dedication"       
   value: "wa-${release-name}-minio"
etcd: 
config:   
 persistence:     
  useDynamicProvisioning: false   
 dataPVC:     
  selector:       
   label: "dedication"       
   value: "wa-${release-name}-etcd"

mongodb: 
config:

  useDynamicProvisioning: false     
 selector:       
  label: "dedication"       
  value: "wa-${release-name}-mongodb"
 
Replace all references to ${release-name} with the release name for your
deployment, and then save and close the file. This is the same name you will
specify as the value of the --name parameter when you install the product.
Important: The release name must start with an alphabetic character, end with an
alphanumeric character, and consist of all lower case alphanumeric characters or
a hyphen (-). For example my-130-wa. 
Find out which worker nodes are available to host the volumes by running the
following command:kubectl get nodes 
From the list of nodes that is returned, choose 4 nodes where you want the
persistent volumes to reside. Make a note of the node IP addresses because you
will pass them as arguments to the --nodeAffinities parameter later. 
 
To create persistent volumes:Attention: You must be a cluster administrator to
create local storage volumes, and the script used to create them must be run from
the master node of the cluster. 
On the master node, change to the /path/to/ibm-watson-assistant-
prod/ibm_cloud_pak/pak_extensions/pre-install subdirectory of the archive file
that you extracted the product files from earlier.
If you want to see all of the options that are available to you when you create
persistent volumes, run the following command:
./clusterAdministration/createLocalVolumePV.sh --help 
The rest of these steps describe how to set up basic local storage persistent
volumes with node affinity.
Run the createLocalVolumePV.sh script to create the persistent volumes.The
parameters to include differ depending on whether you want to enable node
affinity or not../clusterAdministration/createLocalVolumePV.sh [--release ${release-name}] [--path PATH]
[--nodeAffinities NODE1,NODE2,NODE3,NODE4] 
release: Specify the release name that you added to the wa-persistence.yaml
file.
path: Specify a directory path for the physical location of the volume on the
nodes. If you don't, the path /mnt/local-storage/storage/watson/assistant is used.
The script appends two directories to the path: a ${release-name} and a
34

unique directory name for each volume, such as mongodb-80gi-1, to the end
of the path you specify.
nodeAffinities: Include this parameter to create persistent volumes with
node affinity. Pass as arguments the node IP addresses, separated by commas,
for four of the worker nodes that were returned when you ran the kubectl get
nodes command.
 
For more information about the commands used in the script, see Creating a
PersistentVolume. For example:./createLocalVolumePV.sh --release my-130-wa --path /mnt/local-

 Installing on Cloud Pak for Data with OpenShift 
Follow these steps to install Watson  Assistant for Cloud Pak for Data: 
Step1: Purchase and download installation artifacts
Step 2: Create a namespace
Step 3: Apply a security policy to a namespace
Step 4: Extract files from the archive
Step 5: Load the Docker images
Step 6: Create persistent volumes

Step 1: Purchase and download installation artifactsAfter you purchase the add-
on, you download the software as an IBM Passport Advantage® archive file. The
Passport Advantage file for Watson  Assistant contains a Helm chart and images.
Helm is the Kubernetes package management system that is used for application
management inside a Cloud Pak for Data cluster.
Purchase Watson  Assistant for Cloud Pak for Data from Passport Advantage
Use the Secure Shell protocol to log in to the system that you will use as the
master node of your cluster as the root user.
Change to the directory where you want the installation files to be stored.
Download the archive files. The add-on archive download can take up to an hour
to complete over a network connection.
 
 
 Step 2: Create a namespaceCreate a namespace for your application.
Namespaces are a way to divide cluster resources between multiple users, which
can be managed by resource quota. You can use any namespace you want,
including conversation, zen, or any other name you choose.Tip: If you are
installing the helm chart a subsequent time to add another deployment of the add-on
to the same cluster, then skip this step. You will install the subsequent deployment
in the same namespace as the one being used for the previous deployment. 
Log into OpenShift and Docker:oc login
docker login -u $(oc whoami) -p $(oc whoami -t) {docker-registry} 
{docker-registry} is the address of the internal OpenShiftDocker registry.
For example docker-registry.default.svc:5000/
From the  Kubernetes command line interface tool, create the namespace in
which to deploy the service. Use the following command to create the
namespace::oc new-project {namespace-name} 
Make sure you are pointing at the correct OpenShift project::oc project {namespace-name} 
{namespace-name} is the Docker namespace that hosts the Docker image.
This is the namespace you created earlier.

 Verifying that the installation was successful 
To check the status of the installation process: 
Check the status of the deployment by using the following command:watch kubectl
get job,pod,svc,secret,cm,pvc --namespace namespace-name 
Important: Be sure to give the product time to be deployed. The pod that hosts the
Recommends microservice takes 30-45 minutes to reach the Running state. 
helm status --tls {release-name} 
Note: The --tls argument is required for a stand-alone deployment only. 
Take one of the following actions:
If a pod fails, try to determine the cause and fix it.
Run the following command to see logs for the pod:kubectl logs {podname} -n
{namespace-name} -f --timestamps 
If you cannot resolve the cause of the problem and need to start the
installation over, complete the steps in Uninstalling the service, so you can
start over with a clean set of nodes.
If the deployment process was successful, test Watson  Assistant by running a
test Helm chart.
From the Helm command line interface, run the following command:helm test --
tls {release name} --timeout 900 
If one of the tests fails, review the logs to learn more. To see the log, use a
command with the syntax kubectl logs {podname} -n {namespace-
name} -f --timestamps. For example:kubectl logs my-release-test -n {namespace-
name} -f --timestamps 
To run the test script again, first delete the test pods by using a command
with the syntax kubectl delete pod {podname} --namespace
{namespace-name}. For example:kubectl delete pod my-release-test --namespace
{namespace-name} 
You must delete all of the {podname} pods, not just the one that failed, or
the other tests will fail also.
Uninstalling the serviceIf you need to start the deployment over, be sure to
remove all trace of the current installation before you try to install again.

 Provisioning an instance of the add-on 
You can provision up to 30 instances of Watson  Assistant per deployment of
Watson  Assistant. 
From the Cloud Pak for Data web client, go to the Add-ons page.
Find the Watson  Assistant add-on and click it.
Click Provision instance.
Click Create an instance.
Name the instance.This is the instance you will share with the users in your

 Next steps 
Use the Watson  Assistant product user interface to build training data and a dialog

To learn more about the service first, read the overview.
To see how it works for yourself, follow the steps in the getting started tutorial.
For help managing the cluster, see Cluster management tasks.
 
 Troubleshooting issues 
The first step to take if you hit an installation issue, such as a cluster node is not
starting as expected, is to get logs from the cluster which can provide more detail. 
To get log files, complete the following steps:
Log into the cluster with administrator credentials.
Run the following command to get a list of the jobs that are currently running in
the cluster and whether the job was successful:kubectl get jobs 
For any jobs that show a success status of 0, get the log file for the job by
entering the following command:kubectl log {job-name} -f 
 
To check the configurationIf you want to check what configuration settings were
applied to a deployment when it was set up, you can run the following command: 
helm get <release-name> --tls 
The user-provided configuration values are listed at the start of the information that
is returned. 
 
Can't create a session using the APIProblem: You get a 500 response and see
an error, such as "You can't write against a read only slave." when
trying to use the v2 API to create a session. 
Cause: Redis sometimes applies the wrong roles to resources. 
Solution: Restart the Redis pods. Make a note of the replica numbers for Redis
server and Redis sentinel first. Scale the Redis server and Redis sentinel replicas
down to 0 and then scale them back to their original numbers. For details, see To
scale the number of replicas. 
 
 
Parent topic:Installing AI add-ons

 Developing on the Cloud Pak for Data platform 
IBM® Cloud Pak for Data includes platform-level APIs. Some Cloud Pak for Data
add-ons also include APIs.  
 Cloud Pak for Data APIs 
The Cloud Pak for Data APIs enable you to integrate with and extend the features
that are provided in Cloud Pak for Data.  
 The Cloud Pak for Data APIs fall into the following categories:
Platform
These APIs enable you to connect to your Cloud Pak for Data deployment,
manage the users who have access to the deployment, and manage user roles.
Governance
These APIs enable you to add custom assets to your enterprise data catalog.
After you add the assets to the catalog, you can specify the relationship
between the custom assets and apply rules and policies. The governance APIs
enable you to unleash the true value of your custom assets. By bringing them
into Cloud Pak for Data, you can use them in your analysis. 
Analytics
These APIs help you simplify your data so that you can spend less time
wrangling and more time experimenting to derive actionable insight. You can
use the Analytics APIs to:
Manage analytics projects, project assets, and collaborators
Manage jobs
Create project releases
Deploy web services, jobs, and apps
 The Cloud Pak for Data also includes an API for monitoring the status of the API
server. 
 
 Accessing the Cloud Pak for Data APIs 
The Cloud Pak for Data APIs are automatically deployed and available with your
Cloud Pak for Data instance.  
Access the APIs by appending /icp4d-api/docs to your deployment URL. For
example, if your Cloud Pak for Data instance is deployed at
https://icp4d_server:31843, then you can access the APIs at:
https://icp4d_server:31843/icp4d-api/docs 
 
 Add-on APIs 
If you deploy one or more of the following add-ons with Cloud Pak for Data, you
have access to additional APIs.

 Developing applications with IBM Streams 
You can develop streaming applications in Python by using the IBM® Streams
notebook templates. These applications are run in an IBM Streams add-on instance
in IBM Cloud Pak for Data.  
 This feature is available only if your administrator configures the Streams
add-on. 
Streaming applications meet the need for real-time data processing and are
intended to run indefinitely. For example, consider a company whose product scans
traffic sensors across the world to determine traffic patterns and trends. Because
there is always a car passing by, there is a perpetual need to process data. The
application that processes these large volumes of data must also be able to run for
an indefinite amount of time. 
After you provision IBM Streams add-on instance in Cloud Pak for Data, you get an
instance of IBM Streams, ready to deploy and monitor your streaming applications.
For more information, see Provisioning the IBM Streams add-on instance. 
Use the notebook templates as a starting point to develop your own streaming
applications. 
Use IBM Streams Studio to develop streaming applications that you can submit to a
running Streams instance in Cloud Pak for Data. For more information about using
Streams Studio, see Developing with Streams Studio. 
Use REST and JMX APIs to monitor and manage a provisioned Streams instance.
In addition, use REST APIs to monitor and manage the corresponding build service.  
 
IBM Streams notebooks 
 Notebook templates are available to help you get started with IBM Streams in
IBM Cloud Pak for Data.
Supported packages with the Streams Python API for the IBM Streams add-
on 
 These packages are supported by the IBM Streams add-on to provide analytics
and adapters. 
Monitoring IBM Streams by using REST and JMX APIs 
 The IBM Streams add-on provides a REST API for monitoring and managing a
provisioned Streams instance and the corresponding build service. The add-on
also provides a JMX API for monitoring and managing the provisioned Streams
instance.

 IBM Streams notebooks 
Notebook templates are available to help you get started with IBM® Streams in IBM
Cloud Pak for Data. 
 About this task 
 
 This feature is available only if your administrator configures the Streams
add-on. 
The easiest way to get started with IBM Streams in Cloud Pak for Data is to use the
notebook templates. These templates provide the steps and code samples to create
streaming applications that use the IBM Streams Python API. They also
demonstrate how to deploy these applications to the Streams instance in Cloud Pak
for Data. 
You can find the Streams notebook templates on the Getting started page in Cloud
Pak for Data. These templates include the following code samples and sample
applications:
Streams Rolling Average sample application
 If you are new to Streams, get started by using this notebook template. This
template provides detailed instructions on how to create a streaming Python
application, which simulates a data hub that receives readings from sensors.
You can find examples of how to perform the following tasks:
Set up your data connections.
Create a streams processing application by creating a Topology object,
defining sources, analyzing data, and defining the output.
Submit a job to the StreamsStreams instance to start the streams processing
application. Applications that run on the Streams instance are called jobs. 
Connect to the job to view data.
Cancel the running job.  
 
Streams basic template
If you are familiar with Streams and need a few code cell examples, use this
template to get started. This template includes all Python code cells that you
need to perform the following tasks:
Create a streams processing application.
Submit a job to the Streams instance. 
View the data collected by the streams processing application.
Cancel the running job when needed.
 
You can modify the template cells as needed to create your own streams-
processing applications. 
Database Sample application
This sample application demonstrates creating a Streams Python application to
connect to a Db2® Warehouse database, perform some SQL queries, and view
the results. It includes all Python code cells that you need to perform the
following tasks:
Set up your data connections.
Create a streams processing application.
Submit a job to the Streams instance to start the streams processing
application.

Set up your data connections.
Create the application.
Submit a job to the IBM Streams instance to start the streams processing

Connect to the job to view data.
Cancel the running job.
 
 
 Procedure 
 
To use the IBM Streams notebook templates: 
On the Getting started page, click the Analyze tab.Optionally, you can access the
Create Streams notebook window:  
From the project page, go to the Assets page and click add notebook.
On the My Instances page, click the Jobs tab, and click Create notebook.
Click Create a streaming analytics notebook.

Select a Streams notebook template and click Create.
If you are new to Streams and need detailed instructions to get started, select
the Streams Rolling Average sample application.
If you are familiar with Streams and need a few code cell examples to get
started, select the Streams basic template. 
Select the add credentials cell and click Connect to instance to insert the
credentials for the add-on. 
Edit your notebook as needed.
To run your notebook, click Cell  > Run All.
To monitor your jobs, you can view the job status information and health
summary on My instances page.
You can cancel the job from the notebook or from the Jobs tab in My Instances.
 
 Results 
 
When you run one of the Streams notebook templates, the application that is
defined in the notebook is submitted to the Streams build service for compilation. If
compilation is successful, the application will be run on the Streams instance. The
notebook templates also show how to retrieve data from the running job.  
 What to do next 
 
To dig deeper into Streams application development, see Developing IBM Streams
applications with Python and the IBM Streams Python API reference.

 Monitoring IBM Streams by using REST and JMX
APIs 
The IBM Streams add-on provides a REST API for monitoring and managing a
provisioned Streams instance and the corresponding build service. The add-on also
provides a JMX API for monitoring and managing the provisioned Streams instance. 
 Procedure 
 
To determine the URLs for accessing the REST and JMX APIs and documentation: 
Locate the add-on instance that you want to manage: 
Click the Add-ons icon ( ) from the IBM Cloud Pak for Data web user
interface.
From the navigation menu, click My instances or Administer > Manage
instances.
Click the Provisioned Instances tab.
 From the add-on instance options menu for the add-on instance that you want
to manage, click View Details.
Determine the URLs for the API you want to use.
 To access the API, use the appropriate REST or JMX endpoint URL from the
Endpoints section. 
 
To access the API documentation, build the appropriate documentation URL by
combining the server and port portion of the endpoint URL with the
documentation path.
